user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>

Another agent reported that the target code violated the Rule 17.2.
Here is the comment from the agent.
<violation scenario>
Indirect recursion is possible: UT_ExecuteVaHandler calls UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(...). UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs looks up the UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER entry and, if present, invokes that final handler (via the VaHandler function pointer). If that final handler is UT_ExecuteVaHandler (either because it was previously registered for the same FuncKey, or because DefaultHandler passed to UT_ExecuteVaHandler is UT_ExecuteVaHandler and gets registered via UT_SetVaHandlerFunction), the call chain becomes UT_ExecuteVaHandler -> UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs -> (final handler) UT_ExecuteVaHandler, i.e. indirect recursion. This violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2.
</violation scenario>

Your job is to insert logging code to capture the control flow and state information of the program.
Insert logging code so that other agents can reproduce and get evidence for the violation scenario.
<response format>
- test_code: a modified UT_DefaultStubImpl code that contains useful probe functions that print useful logs to a file "/tmp/logs/430.txt". The logs should contain the control path and state information of the violation scenario. If test code is not required to validate the scenario, you can leave this blank.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_DefaultStubImpl:
```c
int32 UT_DefaultStubImpl(const char *FunctionName, UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, int32 DefaultRc, ...)
{
    int32   Retcode;
    va_list va;

    va_start(va, DefaultRc);
    Retcode = UT_DefaultStubImplWithArgs(FunctionName, FuncKey, DefaultRc, va);
    va_end(va);

    return Retcode;
}
```
</target_code>

<instruction>

Please provide the modified UT_DefaultStubImpl code.

The information below explains how I’ll use the function you provide. Please use it as a reference when generating code.
1. Replacement
  - I will parse your function and replace the original UT_DefaultStubImpl with it.
  - Your function must have the exact same signature as UT_DefaultStubImpl.
  - It must be a complete, self-contained definition; (no omissions, placeholders (e.g., "..."), or comments indicating skipped/omitted logic.)
2. Logging / reachability
  - I will run a test suite that is guaranteed to call UT_DefaultStubImpl to check logs.
  - Your function MUST preserve the original logic of UT_DefaultStubImpl as much as possible.
  - The log output must not be empty. Even if you are verifying dead code, UT_DefaultStubImpl will be reached; insert a minimal probe/log to demonstrate that the target function was entered.
3. Coverage
  - I will run the same test suite to measure coverage.
  - Test outcomes must match those of the original code.
  - If reproducing the rule violation necessarily causes a crash (e.g., the violation inherently triggers a crash), that is acceptable; otherwise, your function should not crash under the existing test suite so coverage can be measured.
4. Test code constraints
  - The test code MUST preserve the original logic of UT_DefaultStubImpl as much as possible.
  - DO NOT introduce new violations to demonstrate your scenario.
  - The test code MUST be compilable and executable.
  - The test code MUST include line breaks.
  - You MUST NOT define the main function.
  - You MUST NOT define macros.
  - You MUST NOT REDEFINE any existing identifiers, such as macros, static/global variables, or functions.
  - Do not break string literals or include stray/unmatched double quotes; the code must parse cleanly with no quote-related errors.

These are common mistakes of generated codes. Do not make these mistakes:
- Redefining existing functions, variables, types, or macros.
- Broken string literals or unmatched quotes.
- Invoking undeclared function.
- Using undeclared member in a struct.
- Invoking functions with wrong parameter type.

</instruction>
